entry.content:
How Does Dry Ice Blasting Work?

Dry ice blasting is a non-destructive cleaning process that uses solid carbon dioxide to dislodge residue while leaving the surface intact. Similar in concept to pressure washing, dry ice blasting uses compressed air to project media toward a surface at a high velocity. In this case, the media are carbon dioxide particles, which form solid pellets when cooled to -109.3 degrees Fahrenheit. Three immediate results can be obtained by blasting frozen carbon dioxide on a surface:

  • The surface's contents freeze and fracture due to thermal shock before the pellets even make contact.
  • High-speed collisions between pellets and brittle contaminants break down unwanted residue into smaller pieces.
  • Exposure to room temperature air causes the dry ice to rapidly vaporize, resulting in an explosive effect that dislodges more debris.

How to Use Abrasive Blazing

  • Abrasive blasting offers flexibility because of the variety of media available. The media chosen can be customized to fit the surface material and the contaminant being removed. When the surrounding surface is free from electrical and mechanical components, such as concrete silos, brick walls, or other steel structures, abrasive blasting can be used. The surface can also be profiled to allow for future applications or to shape the surface. Abrasive blasting requires cleanup of media and will not work in indoor areas that can't handle dust and excess mess.
  • Abrasive blasting offers flexibility because of the variety of media available. You can customize the media to match the material or the removal of the contaminant.
  • Abrasive blasting is ideal when the surface and surrounding area has no electrical or mechanical parts that could be damaged through the media being used, such as a sturdy brick wall, a concrete silo, or steel equipment.
  • This method is also used when the surface needs to be profiled for another application or shaping of the surface needs to happen.
  • Abrasive blasting will require cleanup and removal of the media, so for indoor spaces that cannot handle excessive mess and dust, abrasive blasting may not be ideal.

What is Dry Ice used in Cleaning?

Dry ice blasting and cleaning uses compressed air to push CO2 pellets from a tube using a narrow tip that is aimed at the surface. Although it looks much like pressure washing or sand blasting, the big difference is that dry ice is - dry. Because the CO2 is cold (109 degrees below zero), dirt molecules shrink and are released from the surface. The ice pellets become gas when they hit the surface. This creates a molecular blast that removes dirt, grease, and paint from the surface without significantly cooling it.

  • The only thing left to do is sweep up the residue of paint, ink, resins, asphalt, grime, adhesives or whatever has been removed from surfaces. No waste water. No chemical drainage. No sand or plastic beads scattered around. The CO2 solid pellets dissipate into the air and are absorbed by the atmosphere.
  • There is no dust or detritus from dry ice blasting that can be trapped in or foul up either the machinery being cleaned or nearby equipment.
  • The pellets are non-toxic; pose no workplace hazard to people or equipment, and meet EPA, USDA and FDA guidelines.

With Ice Cleaning, you no longer have to take apart industrial equipment, move it to a cleaning area, and then move it back to the manufacturing floor to be reassembled. This allows you to clean it in situ, which greatly reduces downtime. The dry ice blasting nozzle is agile for reaching most exposed areas. You can clean the entire thing by doing some in-place disassembly if necessary.

entry.content:
Industries and Applications of Dry Ice Blasting

Dry ice blasting is an effective solution for removing unwanted contaminants and residues from the production process, such as:

  • Oils
  • Adhesives
  • Resins
  • Paints
  • Greases
  • Asphalt tars
  • Biofilms
  • Aerospace. The aerospace sector relies on dry ice blasting to remove mastic from parts; clean turbine blades; remove labels from fuselage; and clean hydraulics, electrical components and circuitry, and landing gear.
  • Automotive. Dry Ice Blazing is excellent for cleaning undercarriages and engine components, as well as wheels and axles and automotive production equipment.
  • Power plants and electrical equipment. Dry ice blasting is often used to remove oil residue and/or corrosion from power generation equipment, such as turbines and generators. Dry ice blasting is also used in nuclear decontamination and for resin removal in the production of transformers.
  • Fire remediation. After a fire, dry ice blasting can be used to remove any charring or ash from other usable components.
  • Foundries and metal production. This process is used by foundries for cleaning molds and pressing equipment, stripping paint and rust, deburring and cleaning welder robots, residue removal and many other purposes.
  • Mold remediation. Dry ice blasting is a great option for applications that need sanitation.

Here are a few of the benefits to dry ice blasting:

  • No machine disassembly and reassembly is needed - this means companies won't have much unproductive downtime.
  • A quicker clean, that's non-abrasive, non-conductive, non-flammable.
  • There is no secondary waste or cleanup, which saves money on labor and expenses.
  • Companies that have used other methods of cleaning may find it difficult to reach tight areas with our blasting nozzles.
  • Environment-friendly - Meets the requirements of USDA, FDA, and EPA.
  • Safe for employees - no exposure to chemicals or grit media

  • Soda blasting. Abrasive blasting can be used in a variety of ways, including soda blasting.
  • You can pressure wash. Pressure washing, like dry ice blasting is not abrasive. It does not cause any harm to the environment by emitting or toxic chemicals. In contrast, this method is electrically conductive and require wastewater disposal.
  • Tools for hand. These tools can be used in an environmentally friendly manner, do not use toxic substances, are non-conductive and don't require special waste management. Hand tools have a lot of disadvantages, including abrasiveness and additional labor requirements.

Dry ice blasting offers safety advantages that are not available with other industrial cleaning techniques. These are the most important:

  • Emissions and elimination of toxic chemicals
  • Reduced waste of cleaning solutions
  • Prevention of surface degradation from abrasives

Dry ice blasting is a good solution for everything from removing heavy slag to cleaning sensitive semi-conductors. This is a fast and simple process that can be done quickly at a low cost.

  • Uncomplicated: there is no grit or dust left behind even though the technique is as effective as abrasive sandblasting
  • It is cost-effective: Many machinery can be cleaned online or with little downtime. There are no disposal costs or time losses.

Dry ice is a great way to clean any grime-covered surface without damaging it. Unlike sand, bead blasting, or chemicals, dry ice (CO2) pellets will not leave pits or scratches. CO2 is not a hazardous chemical, unlike most industrial cleaning solvents.
